Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Protein Purification system acquisition to support Bioengineering Red Fluorescent Tag for in vivo Microscopy

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration: The protein purification system that is requested with this proposal is an essential piece of equipment for research characterizing and bioengineering light sensitive proteins from cyanobacteria. It is necessary to separate proteins from the E.coli expression system that are used for bioengineering proteins. The focus of The Spiller Lab is to engineer a small, bright red fluorescent protein tag for in vivo microscopy. Undergraduate, post baccalaureate and glide-year students at Mills College are engaged in the laboratory work.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This MRI grant has funded Protein Purification system acquisition to support Bioengineering Red Fluorescent Tag for in vivo Microscopy. Mills undergraduates and post baccalaureate students have benefited by having this modern equipment in Mills research laboratory for their training and for their participation in leading edge research projects.

The BioRad DuoFlow Chromatography System was purchased and installed in a refrigerator in Mills undergraduate research laboratory. This acquisition met specific objectives with the addition of this system to our laboratory equipment. For example, our researchers and students can now separate our engineered protein from the E.coli cells, which produce it for us. The E.coli has been transfected with our engineered DNA plasmid. The plasmid has the genetic sequence to instruct the E.coli bacteria to make the engineered red fluorescent tag. The bacteria can be thought of as microscopic factories, which transcribe and translate the engineered DNA into its protein form. The BioLogic Duoflow allows us to streamline the separation of our engineered red fluorescent protein tag from the E.coli’s soluble cellular debris. The BioLogic DuoFlow system has two pumps and can change buffering systems sequentially as the macerated and ultra-centrifuged cell contents flow over two different columns and into collecting vessels. With this new equipment we purify our desired protein. We have been able to move our research objectives forward toward constructing a red fluorescent-tagged actin and a red fluorescent-tagged tubulin plasmid vector. We also have a possible candidate for an additional tag from a different T. elongatus gene (tlr0924). The cyanobacteriochrome T. elongatus  gene family has 5 candidate genes that may be useful for their ability to fluoresce red wavelengths in the 660nm to 700nm range. The protein purification equipment can be used in the on-going project. In addition, the red fluorescent tag itself is a very interesting protein. Currently, collaboration is underway with for an X-ray crystallography project with researchers and students from University of California Berkeley and The Advanced Light Source at Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratories (LBNL) to crystalize the small bioengineered red fluorescent protein moiety. Our pet name for it is SmuRF protein (Small unexpected Red Fluorescent). The equipment will be shared for our common goals to crystallize and determine the structure of the bioengineered protein that we have isolated at Mills. Protein purification is a very important part of the crystallization process. The project provided opportunities for training and professional development for Mills students. These students gained experience with a cutting edge research project in a well-equipped laboratory. Mills undergraduates participated in many poster sessions at national society meetings and at Mills College. If they go into scientific research in an academic or business or an industrial setting they will have relevant training.
